description.narrative:
Project's focusThe experience of compiling practices for the sake of sending to international awards has been relevant, and successful for its time, but limited for not being able to respond effectively to the demand for knowledge. The Latin American and Caribbean Forum on Best Practices has managed to sustain a network of urban actors in the region, compile and review practices for visibility in the Dubai International Award, feed the database of UN-Habitat, and produce several publications over the years.During the last few years, the project financed by the Ministerio de Fomento, has been promoting activities and developing outputs to build a regional knowledge management strategy. The idea is to achieve significant impacts by working towards a more formal knowledge management program that is demand-driven and based on the logic of going to scale addressing the themes of the New Urban Agenda. In addition, the goal is to also take advantage of internal projects to promote the exchange of the tools and methodologies in place towards achieving sustainable urban development.ROLAC's knowledge management strategy has been drafted and is in the process of approval. Its concentrates efforts in its comparative advantages and aims to foster a complete knowledge management cycle, from identification to transfer and communication of projects and practices. In other words, takes advantage of the work carried out, strengthening the good relationship with its regional partners and adapts institutional methodologies to the region's specificities. The goal here is not to replicate solutions, but to proof methodologies in the territory via project implementation, learn lessons from its implementation and offer such solutions combined with other specificities to other contexts and scenarios. The overall goal is to address local challenges with an integrated approach to foster sustainable urban development. The knowledge cycle should work in coordination with project implementation and communication to provide input for future ROLAC's projects based on the process and lessons learned both internally and externally.In this way, its important to recognize strategic partners such as the Forum and continue to work collaboratively to support their work as a strong and revitalized regional actor. They have great capillarity in the region and can be important interfaces of methodologies and practices in the local level.Also in line with this strategy, the second component of this project, aims to advance beyond the first stages of the knowledge management cycle, namely the identification and systematization of projects, to a more-hands on approach toward the knowledge transfer of lessons learned to new projects. The idea is that the project receiving these inputs can avoid errors and maximize its results. Flagship Initiatives and their potentialVarious of the New Urban Agenda strategies and studied concepts have been put in place in the last few years: city extensions, city infills, NUP, housing at the centre, three-pronged-approach (urban legislation, urban planning and design and urban economy). Once these principles are used they must adapt to local context and respect traditions and culture in order to guarantee success. The scope, setting, phase, decision processes and stakeholders influence the opportunities to the success of the project. These concepts have been proofed in a few countries through concrete projects and have shown positive results and lessons learned, yet are still in the process of being tailored. In this way, these projects offer solutions that are more consistent with the region, yet can continue to incorporate new regional inputs and variables to the discussion on sustainable urban development. Please see attached list of flagship projects in the region. The flagship projects have a huge potential for cities looking for similar knowledge on the most varied themes. In other words, not to tap nor transfer this knowledge forward in effective ways, would mean a loss of the enormous potential of this asset. The transfer exercise would help further the process of sustainability and ensure that implemented practices are continuously improved. Ultimately the transfer of existing knowledge may create win-win situations for both recipients as well as providers of successful and innovative practices; • For the provider: maximize the use and adaptability of its efforts, in addition to learning from adaptations in new contexts, and • For the recipient: useful knowledge and exchange from a renowned and recognized experience to lead to fruitful results.In this way, these flagship projects will aim to provide an opportunity to leverage the debate on sustainable urban development, improve the understanding and tools to take advantage of opportunities associated with urbanization from an interdisciplinary approach via a concrete approach. The pilot project Achieving Sustainable Urban Development (ASUD), has been implemented in five different countries has the potential to leverage sustainable urban development in the region. In LAC the project was implemented in Colombia, the Colombian national office is in the process of compiling results and lessons learned. This project will also enable a better exchange with the national offices and to learn from their experience, provided it's a regional project. The novelty of the ASUD as well as other projects is its interdisciplinary approach based on three main building blocks, which must work together to achieve the desired results. In other words, good planning and urban design must interact with participatory policy and legislative framework to support ultimately resulting in productive cities and improvements in welfare levels financial system.Both ASUD, like other flagship projects have identified several lessons that are valuable to consolidate this second urban transition in the region and use as a basis to exchange the developed methodologies and knowledge built over time within ROLAC. In this way, this project will work from the built legacy from working with the Forum and its networks as well as with the national offices in the region. In accordance with the above, and based on the example of the already implemented projects, the MOU 2016 aims to "build on the built" (legacy) taking into consideration the lessons learned over the years since Habitat II to seize the opportunities of urbanization in the XXVI century, leveraging the knowledge created to other cities.Considering the work done in recent years, this project aims to:>Add to the efforts made in previous action plans regarding the creation of a critical mass of documented (systemized) projects that exemplify sustainable urban development;>Promote technical capacity of intermediate cities in the region;>Work on the tripod approach of the New Urban Agenda and projects ( "flagship projects")> Addressing the most challenging issues in the region: inequality, insecurity, informality, low tax collection capacity, low investment in infrastructure, low local technical capacity, among others;>Recognize the Forum's work as a network and as entities committed to promoting knowledge management in various themes and with various actors.>Display clearly what has been the Best Practices Program during these 20 years and the important role played by the Latin American and Caribbean Forum, jointly and through ROLAC, in two directions:a) as a network for exchanging experiences and knowledge, and articulation of common interests between Spain and the Latin American and Caribbean region from a multidisciplinary vision andb) for the enormous work of identifying and documenting many good practices, which today are part of a structured Library, easily accessible by all. Link: http://habitat.aq.upm.es/busqueda/bestpr.html/ http://mirror.unhabitat.org/content.asp?typeid=19 catid=34 cid=10264Project´s strategyAs mentioned the project has two focus areas: the first one was to take advantage of Habitat III to showcase the Forum´s legacy to plan for the future. In this regard, ROLAC worked collaboratively with the Forum to develop a few communication materials, including: flyer, poster and video, as well identified 4 best-practices from the Dubai Award to evaluate their impact over the years. The goal is also to start thinking of best-practices in a more dynamic fashion, considering that practices change and can either be outdated or influence other programs and practices along their lives, thus they need to be evaluated periodically. The Habitat III conference also offered an opportunity for the Forum's organizations to participate in dialogues with other networks working with knowledge management. Each one of the Forum's organization was asked to write down their reflections about their exchanges and possibility for future collaboration. This input, as well as the documents that came out of the Habitat III conference together with a strategic vision both from headquarters and also from the region on knowledge management will provide rich material to formulate a white paper to be validated and signed by various stakeholders in order to have a clear vision for the next 20 years. The stakeholders are regional players and partners committed to supporting the means of implementation of the New Urban Agenda. Also, the project will focus on promoting concrete examples of the New Urban Agenda, facilitating exchanges with a wide arrange of cities and offering knowledge management services. Thus, a wide open-call will be launched in the region to promote the opportunity of cities getting to know the flagship projects. The strategy will also be to combine the open call with identified work opportunities to combine supply with demanded knowledge to achieve a significant impact. The open-call should be further discussed with the national hubs in the region for them to also provide input on what is the best way to offer cities that already have strategic partnerships or that are part of a metropolitan area this opportunity. Thus, a consultation process will be carried out and based on this recommendations, a open-call will be developed. In the open call, cities should prove reasoning on how this knowledge transfer contribution will add value to their in place working plans. Communication material will be developed for cities to get to know such flagship projects, and the tools and methodologies used in them will be showcased, in order for cities to get to know the tools of the NUA. The projects will specify what they have done in the implemented regional cities, clearly state principles of the NUA and also mention the participatory process addressing cross-cutting issues (youth and gender participation, beneficiaries, etc). The initial idea is that the two flagship projects that receive the highest number of demands from applying cities will be the projects selected to engage in knowledge transfer. The applying practices will be chosen according to the below criteria by a selection committee. Once selected, the practices will be informed and the city focal point will coordinate with the project manager an agenda to receive a UN-Habitat specialist to exchange. Also the UN-Habitat specialist will ensure that local stakeholders of both projects can dialogue via email or skype to promote peer-to-peer exchange, and if funds allow to also participate in the in-situ mission. The mission will aim to help the applicant city with a long-run plan. Criteria to consider when choosing city: 1. Be an intermediary city in LAC as per definition from the State of LAC cities report of UN-Habitat2. Expressing willingness to implement the integrated programme in a sustainable manner, including its three complementary components3. Proposing co-financing component (in cash or in kind) to the approx. 50-100 K Dollars that the programme will invest in the city.4. Commitment of National/Subnational levels of government to enrich multi-level policy dialogue and/or co-financing the programme.5. Demonstrate commitments to UN-Habitat principles and cross-cutting issues (gender, youth and climate change), as well as security and resilience as other LAC challenges will attempt to be address when choosing cities. The application process will provide the input to carry out the selection process, either through the application process or via strategic exchanges. It is important to note that the transfer of a best practice can take various dimensions and levels and should also be considered a bilateral process, where both sides have a fruitful experience. Knowledge transfer is best pursued through peer exchanges. To date the transfer of this knowledge has been difficult to promote, due to the lack of committed funds for the exercise of peer transfer of knowledge and practices.
To be successful, a transfer exercise must be systematically planned to fully understand: what can actually be transferred, why and how. This Project aims to capitalize in a larger scale, through guided peer exchanges, on the experience and vast assets that has been compiled via local stakeholders.
